headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half Q4 2016 Earnings Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer.  Mr. Messmer, you may begin.
componenttext: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half Q4 2016 Earnings Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer.  Mr. Messmer, you may begin.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. As is our custom, I would like to remind you there are comments on the call today that contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our c
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. As is our custom, I would like to remind you there are comments on the call today that contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current judgment of what the future holds and include words such as forecast, estimate, project, expect, believe, guidance and similar such expressions. We believe these remarks to be reasonable. However, they are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. Some of these risks and uncertainties are described in today's press release and in our SEC filings, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and today's 8-K. We assume no obligation to update the statements made on today's call.
For your convenience, our prepared remarks also are available on our website at roberthalf.com. From the About Us tab, go to our Investor Center, where you will find Quarterly Conference Calls link.
Now let's review our fourth quarter results. Quarterly revenues were $1.265 billion, down 1% on a same-day constant currency basis and down 3% on a reported basis from the year-ago period. Income per share was $0.61. Cash flow from operations was $82 million in the fourth quarter, and capital expenditures were $20 million.
We returned $28 million to our shareholders during the quarter through a $0.22 per share cash dividend. We also repurchased 1.1 million Robert Half shares for $51 million. We have 6.4 million shares available for repurchase under our board approved stock repurchase plan. These results were within the range of guidance we provided last quarter.
Robert Half continued to benefit from a tightening job market and solid service demand domestically and in our non-U.S. markets during the fourth quarter. International staffing operations performed particularly well, and Protiviti also reported year-over-year revenue gains. For a while now we've highlighted on these calls our unlevered return on equity, which remained strong during the quarter at 29%.
I'll turn the call over to Keith now for a closer look at our results.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Max. As Max just noted, global revenues were $1.265 billion in the fourth quarter. This is down 3% from the fourth quarter of 2015 on a reported basis and down 1% on a same-day constant currency basis.Fourth quarter staffing revenues were dow
componenttext:
Thank you, Max. As Max just noted, global revenues were $1.265 billion in the fourth quarter. This is down 3% from the fourth quarter of 2015 on a reported basis and down 1% on a same-day constant currency basis.
Fourth quarter staffing revenues were down 2% on a same-day constant currency basis. U.S. staffing revenues were $845 million in the fourth quarter, down 4% on a same-day basis. Non-U.S. staffing revenues were $219 million, up 5% when adjusted for billing days and currency exchange rates. We have 325 staffing locations worldwide, including 83 locations in 17 countries outside the U.S.
The fourth quarter had 61.4 billing days compared to 62.3 days in the fourth quarter 1 year ago. The current quarter has 63.4 billing days compared to 62.7 days in the first quarter last year.
Accompanying our earnings release is a supplemental schedule showing year-over-year revenue growth rates on both a reported and same-day constant currency basis. This data is further broken out by U.S. and non-U.S. operations. This is a non-GAAP financial measure that offers insight into certain revenue trends in our operations.
Currency exchange rates had the effect of decreasing reported year-over-year staffing revenues by $6 million in the fourth quarter, which decreased year-over-year reported staffing growth rates by 0.6%. Global revenues for Protiviti were $201 million in the fourth quarter with $170 million coming from revenues in the United States and $31 million from revenues outside the U.S. Protiviti revenues were up 5% year-over-year on a same-day constant currency basis.
U.S. Protiviti revenues were up 5% from the prior year on a same-day basis, and non-U.S. revenues were also up 5%. Exchange rates had the effect of decreasing year-over-year Protiviti revenues by $1 million in the fourth quarter and decreasing year-over-year reported growth by 0.5%. Protiviti and its independently owned Member Firms serve clients through a network of 75 locations in 25 countries.
Now let's turn to gross margin. Gross margin in our temporary and consulting staffing operations was 38.0% of applicable revenues in the fourth quarter. This is a 70 basis point improvement from the same period 1 year ago and relates primarily to higher pay/bill spreads and lower insurance and payroll tax costs. Our fourth quarter results include $4.3 million in workers' compensation credits pursuant to third-party actuarial reviews of our workers' compensation accruals.
Fourth quarter revenues for our permanent placement operations were 8.9% of consolidated staffing revenues, which is down 30 basis points from last year's fourth quarter. Together with temporary and consulting gross margin, overall staffing gross margin improved 50 basis points versus 1 year ago to 43.5%. Fourth quarter gross margin for Protiviti was $57 million or 28.3% of Protiviti revenues. Gross margin 1 year ago for Protiviti was $62 million or 32.0% of Protiviti revenues.
Staffing SG&A costs were 33.6% of staffing revenues in the fourth quarter versus 32.5% in the previous year's fourth quarter. We ended 2016 with 12,800 full-time employees in our staffing divisions, flat with the prior year. SG&A costs for Protiviti were 18.3% of Protiviti revenues in the fourth quarter compared to 18.0% of Protiviti revenues in the year-ago period. We ended 2016 with 4,000 full-time employees and contractors for Protiviti, up 5% from the prior year.
Operating income from our staffing divisions was $105 million in the fourth quarter, down 11% from the prior year. Operating margin was 9.8%. Our temporary and consulting staffing divisions reported $91 million in operating income, a decrease of 9% from the prior year. This resulted in an operating margin of 9.4%.
Operating income for our permanent placement division was $14 million in the fourth quarter, down 22% from the prior year and producing an operating margin of 14.4%. Fourth quarter operating profit for Protiviti was $20 million, a decrease of 26% from the prior year. This produced an operating margin of 10%.
At the end of the fourth quarter, accounts receivable were $703 million. Implied days sales outstanding was 50.6 days.
Before we move to first quarter guidance, let's review the monthly revenue trends we saw during the fourth quarter of 2016 and so far in January, all adjusted for currency. During the quarter, average daily revenues for our temporary and consulting staffing divisions were essentially flat with the immediately preceding third quarter. In years past, we often had sequential growth during this period. Accordingly, on a year-over-year basis, our growth rates were a negative and became slightly more negative as the quarter progressed. We exited the quarter down 2.5% in December versus the prior year compared to a 1.8% decline for the full quarter. Revenue growth for the first 2 weeks of January was down 2.6% compared to the prior year.
Global permanent placement negative revenue growth rates were fairly consistent throughout the quarter, with December revenues down 4.2% versus a 4.9% decline for the full quarter. So far in January, permanent placement revenues are down 18.8% compared to the same period last year. This information is designed to offer a glimpse in the trends we saw during the fourth quarter and in January. But as you know, we hesitate to read too much into these numbers as they represent very brief periods of time, and they cover holiday periods, which can be volatile.
With that said, we offer the following first quarter guidance: revenue, $1,250,000,000 to $1,310,000,000; income per share, $0.55 to $0.61. The midpoint of our guidance implies year-over-year revenue declines of 2% on both a reported and same-day constant currency basis, including Protiviti and an EPS decline of 9%. We limit our guidance to 1 quarter. All estimates we provide on this call are subject to the risks mentioned in today's press release and in our SEC filings. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Max.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. We ended the year with annual revenues that once again surpassed $5 billion and in fact, reached an all-time high. We saw solid demand across-the-board for our professional staffing and consulting divisions, although clients were more ca
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. We ended the year with annual revenues that once again surpassed $5 billion and in fact, reached an all-time high. We saw solid demand across-the-board for our professional staffing and consulting divisions, although clients were more cautious during the quarter, particularly in December. All indications are that the U.S. job market continues to tighten. Unemployment for college-degreed workers 25 years and older is just 2.5% today. This is placing pressure on the labor supply, particularly at higher skill levels. And the number of temporary workers as a percentage of the overall U.S. workforce remains near an all-time high, a sign employers are building flexible staffing options into their human resources plans with increasing frequency.
We're also encouraged by recent data from the National Federation of Independent Business that showed that while hiring levels did not increase in the fourth quarter, small business optimism reached its highest level since December 2004. Outside the United States, we also see improving markets. Our international staffing operations had a solid fourth quarter.
As we look at the coming year, we are optimistic about the technology investments we've made, which are designed to foster and accelerate continued innovation. In 2016, we migrated our global staffing teams to a new unified front-office CRM system, and we moved Protiviti's North American operations to a new resource management system.
Going forward, we will continue to expand our client- and candidate-facing digital functionality. We've already introduced new online services, including the ability to search candidate profiles on our websites. To serve up the best matches, we've developed intelligent matching algorithms based on nearly 70 years of placement experience, and we're constantly working to improve these algorithms through machine learning.
We offer innovative matching technology to find temporary and full-time job candidates with the right skills, but technology alone cannot produce the correct fit. There are many steps in the staffing and onboarding processes, including assessing the chemistry and business culture fit between the employer and the job candidate and in the case of temporary assignments, the person's availability. Our major competitive advantage lies in the combination of technology and personal service that we provide because it gives our clients the best opportunity to avoid costly and disruptive staffing mistakes and find the right person every time for their business needs.
Finally, a few closing notes about Protiviti, which had a solid fourth quarter. We are optimistic about the considerable opportunities in the year ahead for this business. Protiviti has focused on diversifying its service offerings, developing and growing a loyal client base and hiring, rewarding great talent, all with very good results. This business is seeing solid demand across all practice areas right now. 
At this time, Keith and I would be happy to respond to your questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Operator? Hello, operator?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Mark Marcon from R. W. Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Mark Marcon from R. W. Baird.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if we could talk about the U.S. staffing trends, just a little more color there. Can you discuss to what extent you think it was driven by caution among potential employers and if there was any sort of vertical concentration in terms of th
componenttext: I was wondering if we could talk about the U.S. staffing trends, just a little more color there. Can you discuss to what extent you think it was driven by caution among potential employers and if there was any sort of vertical concentration in terms of that caution? And then to what extent would you attribute the trends to the tightness of the labor supply and the ability to fill the orders?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mark. As it relates to U.S. trends and tone of business, on the one hand, conversationally, our people would tell you that client optimism, client sentiment has clearly and markedly improved. That said, when you look at their actual activity levels
componenttext: Sure, Mark. As it relates to U.S. trends and tone of business, on the one hand, conversationally, our people would tell you that client optimism, client sentiment has clearly and markedly improved. That said, when you look at their actual activity levels as we speak, there's a little sense of urgency. They're waiting for the perfect candidate. They take more time to vet, more time to interview. It's more a wait and see and show me as it relates to the more optimistic view that they have as confirmed by the NFIB study that we cited, the University of Michigan sentiment index, the PMI services that came out today. So our clients clearly feel better. They're more optimistic, but that's in the future. And they're waiting to see more activity in their business before their hiring activity reflects that. I'd say there's not a particular vertical concentration. It's pretty much across-the-board. Our clients across our verticals are pretty much middle-market companies. From a supply-and-demand standpoint, we would observe it's more about demand than it is supply. On the one hand, when they wait for the perfect candidate, you have fewer perfect candidates than you have candidates overall. That said, if there was more urgency in their need, they would be more accepting of the best candidate available. So our people would tell you between having more A-level orders versus having more candidates, they would take more orders than they would take candidates. Having said that, we would observe that our order levels have improved in the New Year, which would be expected following the holidays, which we have experienced again this year. So tone of business, the conversations are more upbeat. There are more -- there's more optimism, but as far as actual hard making placements, getting starts on the temp side, it remains sluggish.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the color. Just with regards to the comment that you made about the orders picking up, obviously, seasonally, that would occur. Is it also -- are the orders improving on a year-over-year basis relative to the recent trend? And typically, when
componenttext: I appreciate the color. Just with regards to the comment that you made about the orders picking up, obviously, seasonally, that would occur. Is it also -- are the orders improving on a year-over-year basis relative to the recent trend? And typically, when you start hearing some more positive chatter from the clients, is there a historical precedent that you would say here's the rough benchmark between the time that they start chattering a little bit more positively versus real action?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, we've never gotten too granular with order data because kind of the quality of the order and the urgency of the order is just as important as the quantity of the order. There's no question there's a lag between better order activity and actual hours
componenttext: Well, we've never gotten too granular with order data because kind of the quality of the order and the urgency of the order is just as important as the quantity of the order. There's no question there's a lag between better order activity and actual hours build, and that lag also changes over time. So we don't want to make too much of the fact that order activity has improved because some of that is seasonal. That said, it's certainly consistent with the better optimism and the better sentiment that anecdotally our people are seeing with their clients.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Very helpful commentary. Keith, it looks like the revenue guide is pretty close to Q4 and kind of the Q1, which typically there's some seasonality where -- I know [indiscernible] I would have [ph] typically expected a step down, but there's a delta in the
componenttext: Very helpful commentary. Keith, it looks like the revenue guide is pretty close to Q4 and kind of the Q1, which typically there's some seasonality where -- I know [indiscernible] I would have [ph] typically expected a step down, but there's a delta in the EPS. Can we just kind of walk through what the delta on the EPS? Is that kind of payroll tax reset? Is that additional investments in Salesforce as you position for this optimism? Or just is there any way to frame kind of the bridge between the EPS guide relative to the revenue? And again, the revenue seemed relatively consistent with the Q4, but there's a delta on the EPS.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, the revenue, the midpoint of the revenue pretty much assumes that the trends existed in the latter part of the fourth quarter, continue into the first. Gross margin, we don't have in the first quarter the payroll tax and insurance true-up credits th
componenttext: Well, the revenue, the midpoint of the revenue pretty much assumes that the trends existed in the latter part of the fourth quarter, continue into the first. Gross margin, we don't have in the first quarter the payroll tax and insurance true-up credits that we had in the fourth quarter, and those credits are about 68 basis points when you add workers' comp to state and federal unemployment. So the absence of those credits impacts profitability clearly. Further, your SG&A dollars are about even year-on-year, but your slightly lower revenues give you some negative leverage. And then Protiviti, seasonally, the first quarter is their seasonally slowest quarter. So if we're looking sequentially, they're -- they never do in the first quarter what they do in the fourth. But I will say this. If you look at that sequential trend, there's less falloff in our guidance in Q1 '17 sequentially in their operating income than was the case in Q1 '16. So that's a good thing. So generally speaking, it's less revenue. It's the absence of the true-up credits. The tax rate will be higher. So the tax rate for the fourth quarter was 37.6%, which was a little under trend, which is 38-ish. Our tax rate guidance for the first quarter is somewhere between 38.25%, 38.5%, and there's always volatility right there. So a little of it's tax rate as well, but it's mostly revenues, a couple points lower, gross margin, the absence of the credits, SG&A, a little negative leverage because of the revenues and a higher tax rate.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. So I mean, it sounds like, fundamentally, things are in this holding [ph] pattern until we get some jolt one way or another from a macro perspective. Just real quick if I could. With the new administration and there's been talk about H1Bs and stuf
componenttext: Got it. So I mean, it sounds like, fundamentally, things are in this holding [ph] pattern until we get some jolt one way or another from a macro perspective. Just real quick if I could. With the new administration and there's been talk about H1Bs and stuff like that going away, how does that impact the model, particularly as we think about the IT business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we do virtually no H1B directly as far as the people that we supply. To the extent that the industry uses fewer H1Bs and therefore, everybody focuses on the domestic supply, potentially that tightens the supply. And generally speaking,
componenttext: Well, first of all, we do virtually no H1B directly as far as the people that we supply. To the extent that the industry uses fewer H1Bs and therefore, everybody focuses on the domestic supply, potentially that tightens the supply. And generally speaking, we would think that's a good thing. I mean, it's already tight at the high end on the development side. But as I said earlier, if you ask our people, technology included, technology development included, they would tell you that they take more orders if they had to choose between more orders and more supply. So we don't expect that the supply thing is growth constraining to a significant degree, and H1B certainly directly won't impact our business. Potentially, they could indirectly impact it.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Silber from BMO.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Silber from BMO.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's Henry Chien calling for Jeff. Just had a follow-up question on the impact of the new administration. I'm just curious what type of initiatives are you most paying attention to from the new Trump administration or policies.
componenttext: It's Henry Chien calling for Jeff. Just had a follow-up question on the impact of the new administration. I'm just curious what type of initiatives are you most paying attention to from the new Trump administration or policies.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the most directly impactful would be the discussed reduction in corporate tax rates. Understand that we're a full tax rate company. We paid 35% [ph] federal, 3.5% [ph] state to get you to the 38.5% [ph] I just talked about. Further understan
componenttext: Well, I think the most directly impactful would be the discussed reduction in corporate tax rates. Understand that we're a full tax rate company. We paid 35% [ph] federal, 3.5% [ph] state to get you to the 38.5% [ph] I just talked about. Further understand that about 97% of our global income is taxed at U.S. rates. So not only is our U.S. income taxed at U.S. rates. Much of our non-U.S. income gets taxed at U.S. rates as well. And further, I would say to the extent there have been discussions about the new tax plan having offsets, we would have no interest deductibility offset. We would have essentially no deemed repatriation tax offset. We would have no border adjust nor a [ph] border tax adjustment offset. So frankly, based on everything discussed so far, we get all the benefit and none of the offset.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And just a question on your hiring outlook. If trends kind of stay in this kind of sluggish environment, how are you thinking about hiring or adapting the temp business in this kind of environment?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And just a question on your hiring outlook. If trends kind of stay in this kind of sluggish environment, how are you thinking about hiring or adapting the temp business in this kind of environment?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: So I'd say it's a little bit bifurcated. Non-U.S., things are improving, particularly Germany, Belgium. There, we're adding to headcount in support of that growth. In the U.S., where our growth rates are a bit negative, we're essentially holding the line.
componenttext: So I'd say it's a little bit bifurcated. Non-U.S., things are improving, particularly Germany, Belgium. There, we're adding to headcount in support of that growth. In the U.S., where our growth rates are a bit negative, we're essentially holding the line. Particularly given the optimism in the air that we hope converts into actual hours built and placements, we're holding the line. So you're going to get a little bit of negative leverage as I just talked about in the short term but we think prudent, given anticipated market conditions.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just want to ask a little more in Protiviti. The gross margin being down year-over-year, it was a tough comp but there's also a comment, in your prepared remarks about side of business and investing in it. So how do we think about the gross margin kind of
componenttext: Just want to ask a little more in Protiviti. The gross margin being down year-over-year, it was a tough comp but there's also a comment, in your prepared remarks about side of business and investing in it. So how do we think about the gross margin kind of there and the margin profile more? More so, I know you talked about first quarter but just more broadly, how we think forward on that business.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Tim, the Protiviti gross margin came in very close to what we had predicted it would. The issue year-on-year is the mix of business whereas a year ago, we had a higher mix of higher-margin FSI regulatory compliance work versus this year, we have
componenttext: Sure. So Tim, the Protiviti gross margin came in very close to what we had predicted it would. The issue year-on-year is the mix of business whereas a year ago, we had a higher mix of higher-margin FSI regulatory compliance work versus this year, we have a lower mix of that, and that which we do have has a lower margin than it did a year ago, although that margin is still higher than our average margin. So it's essentially a mix matter. It's a matter we've dealt with now for a few quarters. The good news is starting in Q1 '17, you're anniversarying that mix issue such that in Q1 '17, we think the gross margin percentage will be flattish versus down year-on-year, which has been for a few quarters now because of that mix issue.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you're not -- is there any reason to think that mix will continue to change, I guess, would be -- I guess your answer says no, but just to be clear.
componenttext: Okay. And you're not -- is there any reason to think that mix will continue to change, I guess, would be -- I guess your answer says no, but just to be clear.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Mix is stabilized. Mix is stabilized. FSI regulatory has flattened out and actually got a little better, quite frankly. So we're optimistic, worst case, it's stabilized and maybe it's a little better.
componenttext: Mix is stabilized. Mix is stabilized. FSI regulatory has flattened out and actually got a little better, quite frankly. So we're optimistic, worst case, it's stabilized and maybe it's a little better.

componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up, second question. The new tools, Max referred to them in the comments, both internal as well as the things you put on the website. The market is obviously not great, so I guess it's maybe tough to tell, but anything you can tell us about to the extent they're having a difference in internal operations efficiency kind of lead flow or is it just too hard to tell, too early to tell in this environment?

componenttextpreview: Well, I guess what we can say is we track the extent to which we're getting leads that then converts to revenue from our digital sources. What's hard to know is how much of that would you have gotten anyway? So if you look just at the absolute numbers, th
componenttext: Well, I guess what we can say is we track the extent to which we're getting leads that then converts to revenue from our digital sources. What's hard to know is how much of that would you have gotten anyway? So if you look just at the absolute numbers, they're encouraging, particularly how early day it is and particularly how we haven't rolled it out thoroughly to all locations. So we feel good about the extent to which we're interacting with our clients in a digital way, which is significantly more than we ever have before.

componenttext: I'll just add what Keith said. It's early and I think the feel will get better and better at using these tools feel as we go forward but results to date are encouraging.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: First, a follow-up on Protiviti . With some of the potential changes in the regulatory landscape under the new administration, what's your outlook on the strength this business has been seeing from increased regulatory scrutiny in areas like financial ser
componenttext: First, a follow-up on Protiviti . With some of the potential changes in the regulatory landscape under the new administration, what's your outlook on the strength this business has been seeing from increased regulatory scrutiny in areas like financial services? And could you update us on perhaps Protiviti's end market mix as it stands today?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. As to changes in the regulatory landscape, as we've talked about on these calls, FSI regulatory for Protiviti is principally anti-money laundering and consumer lending practices and the regulation thereof. The view of Protiviti is the anti-money lau
componenttext: Okay. As to changes in the regulatory landscape, as we've talked about on these calls, FSI regulatory for Protiviti is principally anti-money laundering and consumer lending practices and the regulation thereof. The view of Protiviti is the anti-money laundering piece of what they do probably doesn't get impacted very much by propose changes to regulations. If anything, to the extent it relates to protecting our border, it might get better before it gets worse. On the consumer lending side, while there is some discussion about relaxing the CFPB and other consumer lending, the thought there is based on what's been proposed at least. There's not that there be a significant impact. On the positive side, the discussions about cyber and the importance of cyber and the regulations related to cyber, particularly for FSI, would be an opportunity for us because of the technology consulting practice that Protiviti has is very focused on securing, and cyber would be right in their wheelhouse. Further, Protiviti typically works with the largest of the money center banks, and it's viewed that the banks that would most benefit from a relaxed regulatory environment would be more the middle market, the non-money center banks to the extent SIFI designation moves to a larger size and probably won't impact Protiviti's clients as well as smaller financial institutions. So net-net, the view internally at least as to what's understood today is that it shouldn't have significant negative impact. And on the cyber side, there could be some upside.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. That's super helpful. And then Max, wanted to get your thoughts on the earlier comment from you on the disconnect between the small business optimism and the lack of increasing hiring levels. As you see this translate to actual hard making o
componenttext: Okay. Got it. That's super helpful. And then Max, wanted to get your thoughts on the earlier comment from you on the disconnect between the small business optimism and the lack of increasing hiring levels. As you see this translate to actual hard making of placements referenced by Keith earlier, do you anticipate this to show more markedly for your temp business or your perm business considering the tightness in the labor market and where temp penetration stands today?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think to some extent we're speculating, I'm personally not surprised that you haven't seen a big pickup yet in terms of the NFIB report, for example. Optimism has to precede hiring. And if you looked at the fourth quarter to much of the quarter, people
componenttext: I think to some extent we're speculating, I'm personally not surprised that you haven't seen a big pickup yet in terms of the NFIB report, for example. Optimism has to precede hiring. And if you looked at the fourth quarter to much of the quarter, people seem to be in a very bad mood, negative about the election and so forth. At the end of the day, our types are the types that they want to -- they're from Missouri, wait and see, show me and so forth. So I think the good news is the optimism is up as they start saying more activity and so forth among their own clients, I think their hiring levels will pick up, they'll move more rapidly our placement processes might be condensed. So if you want to be an optimist, there's a lot to be optimistic about. And when Keith talked about the tax proposals that the Trump administration has, I have to admit it's hard for us to constrain ourselves because we don't see anything negative at all at any of that for us, so that would be a very good thing for us I think we'll have to just wait and see what happens. We are optimistic though that these changes, if they continue in terms of optimism and so forth, will lead to increased placement activity as well as temporary activity.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one last quick housekeeping question for me. Could you just comment on bill/pay spreads in the quarter and conversions at both Q4 and Q3?
componenttext: Okay. And one last quick housekeeping question for me. Could you just comment on bill/pay spreads in the quarter and conversions at both Q4 and Q3?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: So bill/pay spreads were stronger during the quarter. The conversions, which often follow permanent placement per se were softer during the quarter. They were around 2.9% of revenue, which was down 20 basis points from the third quarter. So conversion, so
componenttext: So bill/pay spreads were stronger during the quarter. The conversions, which often follow permanent placement per se were softer during the quarter. They were around 2.9% of revenue, which was down 20 basis points from the third quarter. So conversion, softer. Pay/bill spreads, stronger. When you put the package together with the the credit, the true-up credits we got on payroll taxes overall, they were up. Our guidance for the first quarter is that year-on-year, you'll get 10 to 30 basis points of improvement, which is principally higher pay/bill spreads. For the moment, we've held everything else pretty constant.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik from Barclays.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess the near-term trends still look like they're tough for you guys, but there were signs of optimism thinking out a little bit further ahead, and the one question I had around that was capacity. Like, I guess, how should we think about utilization le
componenttext: I guess the near-term trends still look like they're tough for you guys, but there were signs of optimism thinking out a little bit further ahead, and the one question I had around that was capacity. Like, I guess, how should we think about utilization levels today if things do start getting better, like you need to ramp up to have the capacity. Any way to think about that?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I would say in the short term particularly, we are carrying capacity. We pretty much held our U.S. headcounts level for a few quarters. We've added to headcounts modestly outside the U.S. But in the short term, if we see an increase in activity levels in
componenttext: I would say in the short term particularly, we are carrying capacity. We pretty much held our U.S. headcounts level for a few quarters. We've added to headcounts modestly outside the U.S. But in the short term, if we see an increase in activity levels in the U.S., I think there would be a few quarters where we could do that without a commensurate increase in our staff levels.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And I guess just the follow-up was just around the ACA. When it first came out, there was a lot of noise around your stock on what that could mean. Just curious on -- and I guess it ended up being not much of an impact really, but ju
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And I guess just the follow-up was just around the ACA. When it first came out, there was a lot of noise around your stock on what that could mean. Just curious on -- and I guess it ended up being not much of an impact really, but just curious on how you guys think about whether their appeal and replace that will have any impact on the other side.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: So early on, there was optimism about the revenue, the incremental revenue we would get because of ACA with smaller companies just trying to avoid thresholds by using temporaries. That never really came to pass. On the flip side, there was concern that ma
componenttext: So early on, there was optimism about the revenue, the incremental revenue we would get because of ACA with smaller companies just trying to avoid thresholds by using temporaries. That never really came to pass. On the flip side, there was concern that many of our temporaries would qualify for medical insurance that there to 4 had not that never really came to fruition either because those that qualified tended not to elect the coverage. So frankly, just like there ultimately wasn't much impact initially, we don't think there'd been much impact by the replace and repeal or repeal and replace.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the perm business, I guess I just wanted to ask what is implied at the midpoint of the guide or the range of outcomes for Q1? Normally, that business improves sequentially on a dollar basis as you get a new budget year. And is that happening or should
componenttext: On the perm business, I guess I just wanted to ask what is implied at the midpoint of the guide or the range of outcomes for Q1? Normally, that business improves sequentially on a dollar basis as you get a new budget year. And is that happening or should we think that the weak start to January that you referenced is an indication that you haven't seen that normal seasonal type? I realize it's early, but ...

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: The first thing we would say about the January start and if you look back in history, the perm start relative to the ultimate quarter is the least predictive of all, and so you don't have to look back many quarters where you see us down double digits wher
componenttext: The first thing we would say about the January start and if you look back in history, the perm start relative to the ultimate quarter is the least predictive of all, and so you don't have to look back many quarters where you see us down double digits where we end up down much less than that or even up. So we read very little into the start, particularly when the start includes a couple of holidays, which it always does in January. The holidays, they fall in different days. People's patterns about the time they take off differs first to some degree based on which day of the week the holiday falls. So it's a noisy start. It's always noisy, but it's even noisier based on day of week. Our guidance assumes a little bit of sequential dollar growth a little bit but less than what we've seen in the past and, therefore year-on-year, the growth rate would be more negative than our guidance for Q1 than what we just saw.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just the follow-up on Protiviti, outside of the financial regulatory, which you've talked a lot about in recent quarters, can you just give us some color on how the rest of the business is doing? Should we think that -- I think the IP and s
componenttext: Okay. And then just the follow-up on Protiviti, outside of the financial regulatory, which you've talked a lot about in recent quarters, can you just give us some color on how the rest of the business is doing? Should we think that -- I think the IP and some of the other areas that you talked about in the past have been doing well. Are those slowing as well or is this just the comp issue or just any update on demand outside of financial regulatory?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: The story is good there. The 2 other major practice areas Protiviti, our internal audit and the other one is technology, which is principally security, and those have been very solid. The one that's been the most volatile has been the FSI regulatory compl
componenttext: The story is good there. The 2 other major practice areas Protiviti, our internal audit and the other one is technology, which is principally security, and those have been very solid. The one that's been the most volatile has been the FSI regulatory compliance consulting area, but internal audit done very well. You still got PCAOB hammering external audit firms about their clients controls, which ultimately trickles down to the benefit of internal audit that Protiviti benefits from. IT, security, cyber hardly a day goes by where there isn't some kind of breach, something in that area that needs attention. So we've had very solid a year or 2 or 3 in internal audit and in technology security, and we remain positive into 2017.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer from SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer from SunTrust.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: A question for you about the changes to the tax code that are being discussed. I think you addressed it from your own internal cash flow perspective. But historically, when you've seen kind of broad changes to the tax code, what's been the impact on deman
componenttext: A question for you about the changes to the tax code that are being discussed. I think you addressed it from your own internal cash flow perspective. But historically, when you've seen kind of broad changes to the tax code, what's been the impact on demand for your services and kind of where, if anywhere, have you felt a change in demand as a result of these kinds of changes that are being [indiscernible]?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, tax code changes -- changes are always good in that clients have to figure out what's new, what's different and comply with the new regs. So change is always good. The more the change, the better from the standpoint of you need help to comply. Has i
componenttext: Well, tax code changes -- changes are always good in that clients have to figure out what's new, what's different and comply with the new regs. So change is always good. The more the change, the better from the standpoint of you need help to comply. Has it been a major driver of incremental revenue? No. But at the margin, it's good, more so than it's bad.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. In terms of the tech space, have you been hearing from your customers an increased tendency for kind of domestic labor? There seems to be a lot of pushback against offshore to the extent that occurs less over the next 4 years. Do you have any expect
componenttext: Okay. In terms of the tech space, have you been hearing from your customers an increased tendency for kind of domestic labor? There seems to be a lot of pushback against offshore to the extent that occurs less over the next 4 years. Do you have any expectations what that can do for either demand and/or kind of bill rate growth rates?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, because we deal primarily with middle market companies, offshoring has never been -- there's never been that much appetite from our clients for offshoring, and therefore, it's never had that big an impact. Clearly, you hear more about
componenttext: Well, first of all, because we deal primarily with middle market companies, offshoring has never been -- there's never been that much appetite from our clients for offshoring, and therefore, it's never had that big an impact. Clearly, you hear more about reshoring, you hear more about inshoring. There's several terms that get used for domestic, but other than the extent to which it pressures supply, we don't think our business would be that impacted one way or the other.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Reece from Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Randy Reece from Avondale Partners.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about how labor supply is affecting your growth potential in your view, first in the U.S. and then outside of the U.S.
componenttext: I wanted to ask about how labor supply is affecting your growth potential in your view, first in the U.S. and then outside of the U.S.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: So it is true that as clients take more time, they are more selective, and they want only what they view as the perfect candidate. And clearly, our supply of perfect candidates is different than our supply of solid candidates, and therefore, one could say
componenttext: So it is true that as clients take more time, they are more selective, and they want only what they view as the perfect candidate. And clearly, our supply of perfect candidates is different than our supply of solid candidates, and therefore, one could say that our growth is being constrained by candidate supply. However, we wouldn't really articulate it that way because in a normal demand environment where there's more sense of urgency to get your projects done, to get your people hired, they're more flexible in adjusting to market conditions the candidates that are available. So as we said earlier, if we were given a choice today between more quality orders and more quality supply, we would take the orders side. If we had to choose, we'll take both. But if we had to choose, we'll take more quality orders. Non-U.S.,  while supply's always an issue, it certainly hasn't risen to the level of it's a significantly growth-constraining issue.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Hamzah Mazari with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Hamzah Mazari with Macquarie.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is [indiscernible] filling in. You guys had a customer basic as I mentioned in small mid sized companies. Can you give us a sense of whether there's a correlation to your sales from small business mix because that's been up and you guys see that impa
componenttext: This is [indiscernible] filling in. You guys had a customer basic as I mentioned in small mid sized companies. Can you give us a sense of whether there's a correlation to your sales from small business mix because that's been up and you guys see that impacting or going into 2017?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's a hard correlation if you're talking about NFIB optimistic index. There's certainly a directional correlation. And therefore, we're encouraged to see the optimism index improve and, in fact, improved significantly based on what it ha
componenttext: I don't think there's a hard correlation if you're talking about NFIB optimistic index. There's certainly a directional correlation. And therefore, we're encouraged to see the optimism index improve and, in fact, improved significantly based on what it had. I think if you look at NFIB, if you look at the University of Michigan sentiment, they're both back to 2004 levels. That's a really good thing, and we're encouraged by that. But if you do a least-squares correlation on that index versus either of those indexes versus our revenues, I don't think you're going to find a number that's going to be that meaningful overall. But again directionally, I do think it's helpful and I do think it's predictive.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Tong from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Adrian on for George Tong. I just wanted to touch on account specifically and see if you could just discuss trends you're seeing for the U.S. and if there's any specific areas of weakness or increasing competition or if there's just a broad-based
componenttext: This is Adrian on for George Tong. I just wanted to touch on account specifically and see if you could just discuss trends you're seeing for the U.S. and if there's any specific areas of weakness or increasing competition or if there's just a broad-based slowdown.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: So similar to the other divisions, Accountemps flattened out during the fourth quarter. It didn't go down in an absolute sense. It flattened out based on where it had been in the third quarter, and that compares to a typical fourth quarter where you get s
componenttext: So similar to the other divisions, Accountemps flattened out during the fourth quarter. It didn't go down in an absolute sense. It flattened out based on where it had been in the third quarter, and that compares to a typical fourth quarter where you get some sequential lift. Therefore, the year-over-year comparison is a negative but in an absolute sense, it's not negative. It's flat. If you look at the components of Accountemps, the accounting operations portion of Accountemps, which is accounts payable, accounts receivable, payroll, the transactional positions, they're the most impacted. That's expected, that's consistent. They're the most macro-sensitive positions within Accountemps. Our guidance for the first quarter is that on a sequential basis, they decline a little going into the first quarter but not significantly, but you're still going to get a year-over-year negative from that phenomenon.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: And can you discuss the pricing trends in the temp segment and how you balance pushing between bill rates and margins versus targeting a higher fill rates?
componenttext: And can you discuss the pricing trends in the temp segment and how you balance pushing between bill rates and margins versus targeting a higher fill rates?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: So our bill rates for the quarter were up 3.6% year-over-year. That's very consistent with last quarter, which was 3.5%. You're always balancing pricing and volume. We provide our people with a lot of authority, a lot of autonomy in that way, but 3.5-ish,
componenttext: So our bill rates for the quarter were up 3.6% year-over-year. That's very consistent with last quarter, which was 3.5%. You're always balancing pricing and volume. We provide our people with a lot of authority, a lot of autonomy in that way, but 3.5-ish, up to 4% bill rates/wage inflation has been pretty consistent the last few quarters.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Do you think that's impacting placement negotiations or placements for temps?
componenttext: Do you think that's impacting placement negotiations or placements for temps?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, they're always part of the negotiation but with the middle market client, they typically need 1 or 2 people for a few months, and the bill rate is rarely the most important part of that discussion, not that it's not important. I think you'll find th
componenttext: Well, they're always part of the negotiation but with the middle market client, they typically need 1 or 2 people for a few months, and the bill rate is rarely the most important part of that discussion, not that it's not important. I think you'll find that our pricing power has been intact for almost 30 years now. It's something we're quite proud of, but it's also a function of the 1z 2z nature of the volumes at which we place as well as the middle-market accounts that we deal with.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: And our final question will come from the line of Dan from Instinet.
componenttext: And our final question will come from the line of Dan from Instinet.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: We have a very pro-growth President. I mean, this seems unprecedented. Do you think there's any chance we would be getting into a new cycle or do you see this shift as a continuation of the prior cycle?
componenttext: We have a very pro-growth President. I mean, this seems unprecedented. Do you think there's any chance we would be getting into a new cycle or do you see this shift as a continuation of the prior cycle?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure you can parse a reacceleration as to whether that means it's new or whether it's a continuation of the prior. As long as it gets better, frankly, it doesn't really matter what you want to label it. We'll take it and our clients feel better. T
componenttext: I'm not sure you can parse a reacceleration as to whether that means it's new or whether it's a continuation of the prior. As long as it gets better, frankly, it doesn't really matter what you want to label it. We'll take it and our clients feel better. They do. Our clients are more optimistic. You just don't see it yet. But we're encouraged that our clients are encouraged. We'd be more encouraged of our clients were actually acting on it, but they need to get encouraged before they start acting on it, so we'll take what we can get.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, if we did get a tax reform, what would you do with the cash?
componenttext: And as a follow-up, if we did get a tax reform, what would you do with the cash?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: As is consistent with our practice for many, many years, we first look to the needs of our business from a capital standpoint. We deal with those. Our cash has always been in excess of that. The residue, we typically return to shareholders with more divid
componenttext: As is consistent with our practice for many, many years, we first look to the needs of our business from a capital standpoint. We deal with those. Our cash has always been in excess of that. The residue, we typically return to shareholders with more dividends, with more repurchases. And it would be our expectation is that's what we would do with any tax savings that we have. There've been a few questions about whether that tax savings would be competed away by our competitors essentially returning that through lower bill rates back to the clients. I'll tell you in 30 years, we've never seen anything like that, nor would it be our expectation that, that'd be the case here, particularly since it's income tax and not payroll tax. If it were a payroll tax, it would be more germane to the discussion with our clients but since we're talking about an income tax, it's our view that it would not get competed away in that we would then -- our cash flow would benefit -- which would ultimately benefit the level of repurchases and dividends we can do with that cash flow.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2017
componenttextpreview: The bottom line, as Keith said, is there will be more money for purchases. That was our last question. We would like to thank everyone again for joining us in today's call. We appreciate it.
componenttext: The bottom line, as Keith said, is there will be more money for purchases. That was our last question. We would like to thank everyone again for joining us in today's call. We appreciate it.
